simulated_ratings.title: La La Land (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Charming craft and bittersweet ambition, but the musical gloss keeps me a bit detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Precious (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Harrowing yet compassionate, the kind of intimate social drama that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: Butterfly (La lengua de las mariposas) (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle coming‑of‑age pierced by looming history hits my sweet spot for humanist European cinema.

simulated_ratings.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric and watchable, though the mystery never grips me beyond a mild curiosity.

simulated_ratings.title: The Insult (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, nuanced conflict and courtroom stakes that probe history and identity—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Madness of King George, The (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Witty and handsomely staged, engaging more as character study than as emotional gut punch.

simulated_ratings.title: Harvie Krumpet (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky, humane animation with warmth, though its whimsy doesn’t fully floor me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Chumscrubber (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dark suburban satire feels a bit glib and strained despite moments that sting.

simulated_ratings.title: Malèna (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Evocative and melancholic, though the gaze can feel limiting even as the wartime backdrop resonates.

simulated_ratings.title: Dave Chappelle: The Bird Revelation (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp observations, but stand‑up rarely moves me beyond sporadic appreciation.

simulated_ratings.title: Incendies (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Riveting, devastating, and morally intricate—exactly the kind of cinema that stays under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Crash (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An intriguing allegory about conformity and rupture, interesting more in idea than in impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Monsieur & Madame Adelman (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sprawling relationship saga with bite and warmth, if a touch uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Roma (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly monumental—everyday lives rendered with empathy and memory that aches.

simulated_ratings.title: About Schmidt (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry and tender midlife reckoning that earns its pathos without pushing too hard.

simulated_ratings.title: Green Book (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant and well‑paced, but its treatment of thorny issues feels a bit tidy for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate, awkwardly honest slice‑of‑life that I appreciate more than I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Reader, The (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ethical knots and private shame against historical trauma—uneven but absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Hours, The (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegiac and interwoven, its quietly accumulating grief resonates.

simulated_ratings.title: English Patient, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweeping and romantic, occasionally lush to a fault but still affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Leaving Las Vegas (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, compassionate, and unflinching in a way that grips me.

simulated_ratings.title: Truth or Consequences, N.M. (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crime beats without much depth leave me cool despite the momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: Amelie (Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain, Le) (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Delightful and inventive, though the sugar rush keeps me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Brilliantly precise and humane

simulated_ratings.title: Paris, I Love You (Paris, je t'aime) (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A mixed bag of vignettes—charming overall but inconsistent.

simulated_ratings.title: Whatever Works (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light, prickly banter that amuses more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Smile Man (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bittersweet and empathetic, a neat concept handled with grace.

simulated_ratings.title: Biutiful (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, soulful, and hauntingly humane—exactly my sort of downbeat poetry.
